content: The Act may be cited as the "Pre-K for USA Act." It includes findings related to the legislation. The United States ranks 25th in early learning enrollment, with less than 3 out of 10 four-year-olds in high-quality prekindergarten programs. Studies show that access to such programs reduces grade repetition and dropout rates, leading to career success. Every public dollar spent on prekindergarten programs yields a $7 return by reducing the need for remedial education and special services. Children who attend high-quality prekindergarten programs are more likely to succeed in their careers. Every public dollar spent on prekindergarten programs results in a $7 return by reducing the need for remedial education and special services. Attendees are less likely to develop drug problems, commit felonies, or go to prison, and have higher GPAs, increasing their chances of attending a four-year college. About 40% of school districts do not offer prekindergarten programs. Children who attend prekindergarten programs are less likely to develop drug problems, commit felonies, or go to prison, and have higher GPAs, increasing their chances of attending a four-year college. About 40% of school districts do not offer prekindergarten programs, with over half of those that do offering only part-day programs. Texas missed out on up to $118.48 million in Federal funding to expand prekindergarten programs. In response to education funding cuts in Texas, some local governments funded full-day prekindergarten programs after the state legislature cut $5.4 billion in education funding and eliminated $200 million in grants for expanding prekindergarten programs. Certain local governments responded to Texas' education funding cuts by funding full-day prekindergarten programs. These localities, including local governments and educational agencies, would benefit from direct application for prekindergarten Federal program funding. SEC. 3. PREKINDERGARTEN DEVELOPMENT GRANTS. The Secretary of Education, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will award competitive grants to increase capacity for high-quality prekindergarten programs. Grants will be awarded for up to 3 years and not renewed. Applicants include Governors, chief executive officers of States, local educational agencies, or other local government entities. The Secretary will award grants for high-quality prekindergarten programs for up to 3 years, with no renewals. Applicants must submit an application to the Secretary of Education, following specified guidelines. To apply for a grant under this Act, a State must consult with the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education and Care and meet a matching requirement. To be eligible for a grant under this Act, a State, local educational agency, or other local government entity must contribute non-Federal matching funds equal to at least 20 percent of the grant amount. Government entities must provide non-Federal matching funds of at least 20% of the grant amount, which can be in the form of state funding, local funding, contributions from private sources, or in-kind contributions. The Secretary has the authority to waive this requirement in cases of financial hardship. The local government entity can use non-Federal resources or in-kind contributions for matching funds. The Secretary may waive or reduce the matching funds requirement for entities facing financial hardship. The Secretary may waive or reduce the matching funds requirement for entities facing financial hardship when applying for a grant under this subsection. Grants awarded under this subtitle can be used to award subgrants to eligible entities. The Secretary may waive or reduce matching funds for entities in financial hardship when applying for a grant. Grants can be used to award subgrants to eligible entities, who must comply with grant requirements. The Secretary may waive or reduce matching funds for entities in financial hardship when applying for a grant. Grants can be used to award subgrants to eligible local entities, who must comply with grant requirements. The Secretary may not award a subgrant to a local educational agency or other local government entity if they received funding for the program in the same fiscal year. Authorization of appropriations includes $750,000,000 for fiscal year 2016. Authorization of appropriations includes $750,000,000 for fiscal year 2016 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2017 through 2025 for subgrants to eligible local entities. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, an "eligible local entity" refers to a local educational agency, an entity involved in early childhood education programs, or a consortium of such entities. An eligible local entity can be a service agency in partnership with a local educational agency, an entity carrying out an early childhood education program, or a consortium of such entities. Full-day refers to a day equivalent to a full school day in the state and not less than 5 hours. High-quality prekindergarten program is also defined. The term "full-day" refers to a day equivalent to a full school day in the state and not less than 5 hours. A high-quality prekindergarten program is supported by an eligible local entity and serves children aged 3 or 4 based on nationally recognized standards. A quality prekindergarten program supported by an eligible local entity serves children aged 3 or 4, with high staff qualifications based on nationally recognized standards. The prekindergarten program requires children to be 4 years old by the eligibility determination date or have reached the legal age for State-funded prekindergarten. Teachers must have a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field with coursework demonstrating competence in early childhood education. Teachers must meet requirements including having a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field with coursework showing competence in early childhood education, or passing a State-approved assessment. The teacher must have a bachelor's degree in any field, demonstrate knowledge of early childhood education through a State-approved assessment, engage in ongoing professional development in early childhood education for at least 2 years, and be enrolled in a State program. The teacher must have a bachelor's degree, demonstrate knowledge of early childhood education through a State-approved assessment, engage in ongoing professional development for 2 years, and be enrolled in a State-approved educator preparation program. The teacher must have a bachelor's degree and demonstrate competence in early childhood education through a credential, license, or endorsement. The maximum class size is 20 children. The teacher must have a bachelor's degree and demonstrate competence in early childhood education through a credential, license, or endorsement. The maximum class size is 20 children, with a child to instructional staff ratio not exceeding 10 to 1. The program offers a full-day program with developmentally appropriate learning environments and evidence-based curricula. The program maintains a maximum class size of 20 children and a child to instructional staff ratio of 10 to 1. It offers a full-day program with developmentally appropriate learning environments, aligned curricula, comparable staff salaries, and ongoing monitoring for improvement. The program offers aligned early learning standards, comparable staff salaries, ongoing monitoring for improvement, and accessible comprehensive services for children. The program provides accessible comprehensive services for children, including screenings for vision, dental, health, and development, referrals, and family engagement opportunities. The program offers comprehensive services for children, including family engagement opportunities, such as parent conferences and support services, and nutrition services. The program provides comprehensive services for children, including parent input on development, parent education, family literacy services, and nutrition services aligned with Child and Adult Care Food Program guidelines. The program offers nutritious meals and snacks in line with Child and Adult Care Food Program guidelines, along with nutrition education for children and families. It also coordinates with local educational agencies. The program provides regular, age-appropriate nutrition education for children and families, coordinates with local educational agencies, and offers physical activity programs aligned with evidence-based guidelines. The program includes physical activity programs aligned with evidence-based guidelines and additional support services for children with disabilities. The program provides high-quality professional development for staff, including in-class observation, and additional support services for children with disabilities. The program offers on-site professional development for staff, including in-class observation and evidence-based coaching. It also meets education performance standards. The program provides professional development for staff through on-site observation and evidence-based coaching to meet education performance standards and maintain health and safety standards. The terms "local educational agency" and "State" are defined as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The program ensures staff professional development through on-site observation and coaching to meet education performance and health/safety standards.
